headline.main: Now, Choices in Heart Bypass Surgery

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on advances in coronary bypass surgery, which since its inception in 1960's has brought relief from crippling chest pain and significantly prolonged life for millions of people; notes hazards of procedure, including possibility of mental decline; points out that experts say many patients who now undergo bypass surgery could benefit just as much from a less risky and less debilitating procedure: angioplasty to widen opening of clogged vessels and insertion of stents to keep them open; drawings (L)
docs.lead_paragraph: Coronary bypass surgery to circumvent clogged arteries that feed the heart has, since its inception in the 1960's, brought relief from crippling chest pain and significantly prolonged life for millions of people. But as dozens of studies have shown, despite major improvements in technique, better selection of patients and highly experienced cardiac surgeons, bypass surgery is still hardly an innocuous procedure. It is associated with a mortality rate of 1 percent to 2 percent; some patients suffer surgery-related strokes, and in the years that follow, as many as half of bypassed vessels themselves become clogged, requiring another bypass or some other procedure to restore adequate coronary blood flow.
